commentBody:
If the ideal gas law is valid — and it is, then the most devious piece of chicanery a year ago was the work done on the Colts' footballs (only 4, btw), which came in at 12.5 ppi or thereabouts.

How did that happen in 40 degree temps and a cold, steady rain?

The distinct possibility is that the Colts pumped four of them up to 12.5 when they realized their balls were deflating but did not have time to pump up the other eight. An 8th grade science kid could have told Mr. Rhoden the pressure would have dropped as the temperature did.

The Colts panicked and started pumping. (Hey, Chris Mortensen, could you please get your sources to confirm or deny?)

Remember, the Colts initiated the sting; the team had reason to cover its tracks.

And what have the measurements taken during this year's games borne out? We don't know b/c the commish hasn't released them. Wonder why?

For all its hot air, Deflategate ran out of steam about the same time the Pats had won 10 straight (if not sooner), and Tom Brady became the top-rated QB in the league, throwing footballs that you know had to have conformed perfectly with NFL standards.

Based on the results of the 2015 season, Brady has more than proved himself to be on the up and up.

NFL leadership and a small but implacable group of pundits still have a long way to go.

replies.commentBody: Goodell should also reinstate the 2 draft picks he stole from the Patriots.
